name: Belfast City Hospital Planters
short_description: Edible herb garden for the community.
description: Publicly accessible planters featuring rosemary, mint, and seasonal greens near the hospital entrance.

name: Cave Hill Hazelnuts
description: Hazel trees are scattered throughout the lower wooded slopes of Cave Hill Country Park.

name: Helen's Bay Seaweed
description: Excellent spot for gathering dulse and other edible seaweeds from the rocks at low tide.

name: Victoria Park Orchard
short_description: Heritage fruit trees in East Belfast.
description: Established community orchard featuring local apple varieties available for public picking.

name: Lagan Towpath Wild Garlic
description: The wooded banks along the River Lagan are covered in wild garlic during the spring months.

name: Comber Greenway Blackberries
description: A former railway line now acting as a green corridor, perfect for blackberry picking.

name: Incredible Edible Cloughfern
description: Raised beds along the road featuring kale, chard, and herbs for the local community.

name: Minnowburn Sweet Chestnuts
description: Historic woodland site with mature sweet chestnut trees near the Terrace Hill area.

name: Ormeau Park Fruit Trees
description: Scattered fruit trees found in the wilder sections of Belfast's oldest municipal park.

name: Holywood Shore Samphire
description: Found on the muddy shores of Belfast Lough. Best gathered in early summer.

name: Belvoir Forest Sloes
description: The hedgerows around the forest perimeter provide heavy crops of sloes.

name: Divis Mountain Bilberries
description: Low-growing wild berries found across the heathland of Divis and Black Mountain.

name: Incredible Edible Rathcoole
description: Public planters containing seasonal vegetables, maintained for public use.

name: Sir Thomas & Lady Dixon Park Walnuts
description: Occasional walnut trees found in the historic arboretum and parkland areas.

name: Barnett Demesne Elder
short_description: Elderflower and berries by the river.
description: Large stands of elder bushes grow along the meadows and river paths.
